comments.commentBody: Exactly. By embracing Big Sports, schools like Rutgers (one of my alma maters) completely lose sight of their priority: to educate students and advance learning and knowledge. It sickens me to see Rutgers chasing a sports championship at any cost.

Lots of appropriate indignation and outrage expressed in the comments I've read here, toward the abusive coach as well as the enabling Director of Athletics and University President who didn't take appropriate action until the video went public and viral. One aspect that hasn't been highlighted is the salary which the coach continued to receive after his brief suspension and fine assessed back in November - $700,000 per year, approx. $58,000 per month or almost $2000 per day to COACH A COLLEGE BASKETBALL TEAM!!!  What is wrong with us? America needs to address the issue of our misplaced priorities if we are to remain competitive in a global economy that does not suffer fools gladly and is beginning to leave us behind in part because of our foolish obsession with gladiatorial sports vs. real academic and intellectual achievement.

The majority of Rutgers students probably didn't even know who Mike Rice was before this scandal! There is NOT a Penn State culture here of mass sport-fanaticism, and the actions of athletic officials, whose existence most are aloof about anyway, certainly do not characterize one of the most diverse and multi-faceted campuses in the country.

Pernetti and Barchi were instrumental in negotiating Rutgers' migration to the B1G$ conference. Their jobs are safe. I used to love college sports, but in the new "money talks" environment, not so much.
Perhaps in addition to firing him, his punishment should include being pushed around, yelled at, grabbed by the shirt, and having basketballs thrown at him constantly.
I am amazed that not one of the player threw a punch at him.  I certainly would have defended myself and really laid into him.
These are college students. What was he thinking? Frankly, I'm surprised at least one of them didn't swing at him for that conduct.

My mom has been in a nursing home for the last 10 years diagnosed with Alzheimers. She receives extremely wonderful care from a incredible staff. She is went on Medicaid two months after her funds were depleted. It is a terrible disease and not many people can comprehend what it is to care for someone who has the disease. . I am frequently asked, "Does she recognize you" After 10 years are you kidding. More research is needed. The Alzheimers Association was so helpful when we started to notice changes in my mother's behavior. They were supportive and gave me the strength to deal with the situation. More research needs to be done.

The rise in dementia is due to the increase in the population of elderly people due to the baby boom, and to the fact that healthcare is so good that we're all living long enough to GET dementia.  A 100 years ago, or even 50 years ago, many of us (myself included, thanks to appendicitis) would have died years before reaching the age when dementia is most likely to appear.  Those two factors, more than any of the causes you mention, are the primary drivers of our looming Alzheimer's crisis.

It's a great disservice to predict a dire future extrapolating from current data, without likewise extrapolating on recent scientific advances in understanding Alzheimer's, and the likelihood of effective prevention and treatment.

There's a pernicious, misguided, underlying belief that if we adhere to the most negative outlook, we'll do more to combat the problem; or, if we acknowledge positive trends, we'll become complacent.-- In fact, the opposite is true; undue, myopic pessimism leads to helplessness, passivity and lassitude.

I'm saddened by the depressed tone of so many comments here, particularly the underlying guilt of older people. All without reason.

I look forward to more balanced articles. How about one aggregating and discussing current research on dementia, including controversies? How about profiling the scientists and funders involved?

That's horrific. You have to sign a note to dehydrate and starve yourself, instead of what you really want, which is to die quickly, painlessly, and in relative peace. I suppose one can hope (?) that during the dehydration and starvation that the doctors give you enough drugs to dull the days long pain. But, you are right. That is not a good way to "go out," almost like an animal on the road somewhere, but in a hospital with narcotics. Yeesh.

I see the need for "death with dignity" proponents to speak up and legalize euthanasia for those who want it, if they are facing dementia (of any etiology).   I'm an RN and have seen a lot (birth to death).  I'm sure a lot of educated, ethical,  life-loving "boomers" feel this way.  The research isn't going to be soon enough to help me.  This is still "taboo" to talk about openly.  I've put refusal for hydration and nutrition (just "comfort measures") incase of dementia in my living will, but this is NOT a good way to "go out".  Knowing I could have a humane, legal, medically supervised exit would help me to live more fully, joyfully, productively while healthy.  As well, make intelligent financial planning possible.

And of course if they are typical members of their generation their generation they did not pay for these benefits. eg. I call them the welfare generation as they received OAS & CPP pensions and paid only tiny amounts into these programs , let alone the OHIP costs (long-term care) that you suggest amounts to $180,000/year that other generations must pay.

I have 2 parents, age 94 and 95 in long-term care.  They pay almost $4,000 a month to live there, and this apparently only covers 20% of the real cost of their care, which if you do the math, is over $200,000 a year.  Living in long term care makes people decline faster.  Think about it - you take an elderly person with dementia out of their home environment where things are familiar, and put them into a situation that is completely foreign to them, where they have no role in anything meaningful to them.  In both Canada and the U.S., money would far better be spent keeping people at home with the necessary community supports in place.  Right now it is very, very difficult to get consistent care for the elderly, both at home and in long term care.  Some European countries provide money that can be used to pay a family member to care for the elderly.

The major effort should be to determine the cause and to prevent Alzheimer's. The impact upon patients and their families and the maintenance costs upon the health care and social service systems will, otherwise, be overwhelming.

Primary reliance upon drug companies is a mistake. The human and financial costs involved make Alzheimer's a national security issue every bit as serious,and probably more certain than, the threat of war. Our present investment in research, as to cause and prevention, is pocket change as compared to what we spend on military defense and offense.

We must reassess our priorities We must have a "war" on disease and infirmity that is not profit based, but national security based, in the best meaning of that phrase. We must also develop realistic standards with regard to the prolongation of life. Unless there is a radical change in the human condition, it is certain that, as some maladies are prevented or cured, other maladies are in line to provoke misery and fatality, and most survivors will have high maintenance costs. What then?

Inherent in this comment and many others is the idea that treatment is forced on people and the patient is the passive victim suffering the whims of doctors and big business.

The doctor is legally obligated to present all reasonable treatment options available. Failure to do so can result in the doctor being sued for failure to meet "standard of care."

The patient has the legal right to refuse any and all medical treatments offered to them. Patients and their families need to understand this.

Most doctors and healthcare workers are well aware of the absurdities and irony expressed in these comments and would also appreciate a more rational way of dealing with the issues herein. We live in it every day and are more aware than anyone of the absurdity of continuing with medical treatment regardless of situation. Unlike the patient though, we cannot refuse to care.

Patients and their families need to better understand the power they have within the system and to have rational discussions about their desires long before they find themselves in a hospital bed. Have you completed advanced directives?

When proposals were made to compensate doctors for their time to have such rational discussions with patients in 2009 as part of healthcare reform, people labeled such compensation as an attempt by the government to form "death panels".

Perhaps we should each put more thought into how we would like our last days to be and to better understand our rights as patients.
That would be wonderful and I commend you. I truly do. But, this is unrealistic in our society. We are transfixed by the ins and do not want to pay attention to the outs.

You are a wonderful grandchild. But those who don't take care of relatives in home should not be made to feel guilty. My house is multi floors, no BR or full bath is  accessible. I have a very bad arthritic knee and wouldn't be  able to help physically in any sense. Sometimes I need help. I would still need to bring in 24 hour attendant - where would I put that person? The questions go on and on. Many of my friends ad colleagues are in similar situations. And, our kids are just starting out and still need some occasional help.

Wow, thanks everyone -- you really made my day.

I completely agree that the arrangement I have with my grandfather would only work in some circumstances, and no one should *ever* be made to feel guilty for not caring for elderly relatives at home. I did not mean to suggest such a thing.

We have made our situation work in part because I moved into my grandparents house, relocating from NYC to CA on a "temporary" basis when I realized how great their need was. Being flexible emotionally and practically helps. Being in my 30s and fairly physically strong helps. Having had a profound connection with my grandparents and a deep sense that family should "do" for each other helps. In practical terms, we are fortunate that my grandfather planned quite well for his long retirement and there is sufficient money for us to live in a beautiful house and eat good food. That REALLY helps.

What I really want to get across is my sense that I have gotten at least as much from this experience as my grandparents have. I am concerned that with so few models of in-home caregiving, people who otherwise really might be up for the challenge just won't know where to begin and will make uninformed, possibly regrettable choices. We are on the verge of a tremendous societal shift as the baby boomers age. Some of them -- many, I suspect -- will need care. I just want to at least have a conversation about doing it at home, when it's appropriate and possible. That's all.

I have been caring for my grandfather for the past four and half years. He has dementia and will be 91 this May. I am an unpaid, 24/7 live-in caregiver; the costs to me have been great, and grow over time. That said, I love being with my grandfather and treasure the time we have had together. We are fortunate enough to also have some paid help, without which I simply would not be able to provide the kind of care my grandfather needs at this point.

I worry about what will happen as fewer and fewer people have models of in-home caregiving, and are faced with this enormous challenge without having observed it. If you haven't seen someone in your family or extended circle care for an elderly or ill person, how in the world will you go about doing it yourself?

I'd love to have a day or two off, or to get to sleep at night for more than an hour or two at a time, but I am comfortable being a full-time caregiver. My grandparents were absolutely marvelous to me all throughout my life, and it gives me a lot of joy and satisfaction to be able to return the favor now.

Many of my friends from other countries simply cannot believe that in the US, the elderly and ill are sent away from home rather than cared for by their families. Such a practice seems so inhumane as to be beyond comprehension. I hope that in the coming years we can get back to a more human inter-generational system and keep those whose emotional and physical health allow it at home.

Unfortunately, just as younger people, the elderly are responsible for paying for their medical/nursing care. Once they have depleted their savings, they become eligible for tax-payer funded Medicaid. Medicaid will cover the cost of long-term care for the duration of their lives. Medical bills are one of the leading causes of bankruptcy in the US, for non-seniors, as most do not qualify for Medicaid.

We all have the option right now of refusing any medications we do not wish to take. Many doctors will review meds with elderly patients in order to cut down on what's not needed, or what the patient no longer wants to take; if the doctor will not listen, find another doctor. No one needs to sign up for hospice service in order to stop taking unwanted medications, although hospice can be a very good option under the appropriate circumstances.

As the caregiver for my 90-year-old grandfather, I completely agree with what you are saying about the need for less medical intervention at the end of life. I just want to make it clear that in my experience, it's relatively easy -- and often welcome, for everyone involved -- to cut down on medications. If a physician is not open to such a change, that is a sign that he or she is not an appropriate doctor for a geriatric patient. (Or anyone, for that matter!)

Death IS a part of life -- yes. Or as we say in the Book of Common Prayer: In the midst of life we are in death. The denial of death has been and continues to be catastrophic, not just for individuals but for societies.

Neal
When your mom is gone
You will sleep well at night
Knowing you cared for your mother
And did the right thing.

Where do your sisters go
On vacation.
When my parents were ill
We others far away traveled to see
Our mom and also to relieve our sister
Who lived nearby and
Did the heavy lifting.

You are blessed.

I expect most people over 50 have an older family member or at least know someone with dementia or Alzheimers.  My 86 yr old mom has progressively gotten worse with dementia for the last several yrs.  She can't wander off as a hip is totally gone from arthritis. She really just wants to die.  Her almost 20 yrs now boyfriend/roommate takes pretty good care of her.  I'm the only sibling left in the same town, my other 4 sisters live a long way away.  I've been taking care of her finances and doctor issues for the last several yrs and she doesn't have much.  Trying to save up enough of her small income so she can at least get into a care facility on private pay for a few months.  My sisters would help but they are not here.

It's time we had a frank discussion about end of life directives. All people, especially the elderly, need to have living wills and do not resuscitate orders. Absent of this information, hospitals and family members are placed in a terrible situation. Frequently, these important conversations never take place. Family members are forced to make decisions after a loved one is incapacitated. This is not the best time to make important life and death decisions.

We all need to face the fact that we will, one day, die. And nothing we can do will change that. We must make provisions that will make it easier on family members when we face the end.

We need laws to protect doctors who do not want to inflict life-prolonging procedures on advanced dementia patients which may lead to further suffering and morbidity.It is the families who demand extreme life-saving measures: feeding tubes, full code (I have had to inflict terrible pain on demented elderly who are full code:broken ribs, large bore needles shoved quickly into femoral arteries, intubation...), etc.  If I had my way, I would refuse to ever put a feeding tube in someone with advanced Alzheimer's. Currently, if we don't follow the families wishes, we will be sued or worse-prosecuted for manslaughter.

I agree completely.  I can't imagine where they get the number in their study.  I would be thrilled if in-home care for my Mom cost 40,000-50,000 a year.  $20 per hour is more like it, times 24, times 365.  Do the math.  It is a luxury to "die with some dignity at home,"  available to very few.

The costs are phenomenal, and the $7000 per month only pays to be  in the assisted  living.. It doesn't pay for the personal care, if needed. If the person is still in their home, the personal attendant needs to be supplemented by others. You can't be caring for the patient if you are also the housekeeper. The costs are crushing.

The figures for cost of care are incorrectly low. In Atlanta, monthly costs in a facility are $7,000-$8,000, for a range of $84,000-$96,000 per year.  In home care from an agency is $20.00 per hour. So much for your academic research study. I am concerned that other aspects of this study could be seriously inaccurate.  As part of our Advance Directives for Health Care, we should have the right to request termination of life when we have severe dementia. The "person" is actually dead at that point. Only the body continues .

Maybe the government will decide to let each qualified undocumented immigrant "adopt" and be legally responsible to care for an elderly disabled US citizen for a fast track path to citizenship.

Many people who come to the US are from countries that have very strong family values to respect and care for their elders. Many of them would be grateful to do this national service to feel the sense of true pride that comes from genuinely earning the much desired Citizen of The United States of America status.

Most likely our governmental representatives would much rather choose a "corporate" solution. Perhaps they will allow nursing homes to utilize temporary migrant workers to do much the same service with no path to citizenship and at extreme cost to our country through medicaid payments to the nursing homes. That way the corporations that own the nursing homes will see a nice profit on the backs of the taxpayers. The wealthy CEOs of the nursing home industries will no doubt contribute generously to their kind representatives' reelection campaigns.

Notice that with the corporate solution neither the workers nor the elderly citizens have much of a vested interest in each other. To the temporary workers the elderly citizens are just random generic old bodies to care for. To the elderly citizens the workers are random servants that take care of their minimal needs. Nobody really gets to know the other except as a cog in the dehumanizing corporate production line system.
My dad's in the hospital, right now, in the last stages of Alzheimer's.  I truly understand what you are saying.

My Mom died not understanding where she was in time
and who we were
In relation to her.
For a long time she was afraid and confused as her world slipped
From her grasp.
In the end it didn't matter.
Just the love in the room.
It was the most painful thing I have ever experienced.
It haunts me and scares me.

I totally agree with MSPWEHO!   Why are so many in this country eager to go to war, but so squeemish when it comes to end of life choices?  These are often the same people!!   In those few states that have at least gotten to the point of legalizing end of life choice, the requirement is still in place that you need 2 physicians to agree that you probably only have 6 months to live!   This requirement certainly rules out an end of life choice for any kind of dementia, which can go on for years and years!

Over the next decade, as this doubling of dementia starts to come into being, affecting scores of baby boomers in the process, I suspect that America will begin having another important social debate (presuming that federalized gay marriage will hopefully be a settled matter) regarding a person's right to die--and the legalization of physician-assisted suicide.

As a boomer who just watched his mother and aunt slowly and painfully leave this world, before their time and both from dementia, over the course of fourteen years--by the way, spending well more than half of each of their life savings in the process due to their expensive at-home and nursing home care--I can tell you that I would at least consider finding a way to spare my family not only the wrenching experience of witnessing a dear loved one lose their grasp on reality and their own identity, but also hopefully allow my next-of-kin to inherit money that would instead go to weekly pill distribution fees, incontinence supply fees, $8 dollar aspirins and many thousands per month so that I could hole up in what is essentially a death camp, dressed up with cheery names involving words like "Summer" and "Pine" and "Crest."

"Now, I am going to ask you a few questions and then I am going to ask you to repeat those three words I just gave you." the neurologist said to my Mother at her early exams.

I've laid awake more than a few nights wondering whether I might be next.

Yup, my mom is on Namenda and Exelon patches.  Her neurologist and one sister think they are helping.  I don't, I see her several times a week, my sister a couple times a year.  She's in the "donut" hole for 8 out of 12 months and this stuff is over $300/mo then, even with Humana Rx insurance.  Probably double that w/o the insurance.  I take care of mom's finances and doctor stuff and believe we'd all be better off saving that Rx money for a nursing home or memory care unit.  Mom clears about 20k a year with SS and a small pension.  Half goes for supplemental insurance, Rx insurance, and medicine.

Or possibly, older people who choose to go dancing have more intact brains while those who are in the pre-clinical throes of dementia, meaning no outward, diagnostic signs, don't choose to go dancing because remembering the steps would make it too much of a chore and no fun. It's the same with crossword puzzles which are also touted as ways to exercise your brain. My mother did crossword puzzles religiously, more than one often per day, because they were fun. And then eventually they weren't. She's currently nearing the end of her life and has dementia.

Amazing example of scare tactics as I paraphrase from the article:

"Dr. Hurd noted that in addition to the (15% with actual dementia), 22% of people aged 71 and older — have mild cognitive impairment that does not reach the threshold for dementia. 12 percent of those people developed dementia each year, meaning that they experienced problems with memory, concentration and daily functioning that were severe enough to meet the medical definition."

"Of people over 71" is the same as saying "people around 85 years old" based on the Social Security Life Tables. The younger age is used to have the majority of perfectly healthy 71 year olds (like me) with a fear of dementia into focusing on this disease. By the way, if you go on Alzheimers Association web site, you will find a section on "Myths" where they state the number one is "Memory loss is a natural part of aging."

This is simply false, as I document in my personal eponymous website that provides abundant reference to the physiological shrinkage of the brain that universally affects short term memory at the very least.

This subtle distortion of the incidence and seriousness of this affliction also will make less effective the coping mechanisms- humor, camaraderie and acceptance- that has been a part of getting old from time immemorial .
Actually it's the exact opposite.

Dementia has increased over and above that which was predicted given people are living longer.  Thus the cause is, at least in part, environmental.  Toxins in food and products surely contribute. So too does increased consumption of calories.  But most of all the cause is related to a massive increase in consumption of carbohydrates and a reduction in the consumption of (good) saturated fats.  Cease eating pasta and bread and start consuming grass fed butter and pastured egg yolks if you want to decrease your probability of acquiring dementia.  This and increasing social interaction, staying engaged in novel tasks through life, and exercising in moderation are the solutions. Keep insulin levels as low as possible and consume mct oil as well.
